Complete the following Lean 4 code:
```lean4
import Mathlib

open scoped Real EuclideanGeometry

/--
$Γ$ is a plane curve of length 1. Show that we can find a closed rectangle of area 1/4 which covers $Γ$.
-/
theorem putnam_1969_b4
    (Γ : ℝ → EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
    --Note: the problem doesn't say what regularity conditions we should impose on `Γ` - hopefully continuity is enough.
    (Γ_cts : ContinuousOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1))
    (hΓ : eVariationOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1) = 1) :
    letI : Module.Oriented ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) (Fin 2) := ⟨Module.Basis.orientation <| Pi.basisFun _ _⟩
    letI : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) = 2) := ⟨finrank_euclideanSpace_fin⟩
    ∃ (a b c d : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ '' (Set.Icc 0 1) ⊆
      convexHull ℝ {a, b, c, d} ∧ dist a b * dist b c = 1/4 ∧
      --`abcd` is a rectangle
      letI π_div_2 := Real.Angle.coe <| π / 2
      (∡ a b c = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ b c d = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ c d a = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ d a b = π_div_2) :=
  sorry

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_b4
    (Γ : ℝ → EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
    --Note: the problem doesn't say what regularity conditions we should impose on `Γ` - hopefully continuity is enough.
    (Γ_cts : ContinuousOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1))
    (hΓ : eVariationOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1) = 1) :
    letI : Module.Oriented ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) (Fin 2) := ⟨Module.Basis.orientation <| Pi.basisFun _ _⟩
    letI : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) = 2) := ⟨finrank_euclideanSpace_fin⟩
    ∃ (a b c d : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ '' (Set.Icc 0 1) ⊆
      convexHull ℝ {a, b, c, d} ∧ dist a b * dist b c = 1/4 ∧
      --`abcd` is a rectangle
      letI π_div_2 := Real.Angle.coe <| π / 2
      (∡ a b c = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ b c d = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ c d a = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ d a b = π_div_2) := by
  classical
  use Γ 0, Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ 0, Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
  constructor
  · -- Show that the image of Γ is contained in the convex hull of the rectangle
    intro x hx
    obtain ⟨t, ht, rfl⟩ := hx
    simp only [Set.mem_Icc, Set.mem_image] at ht
    have h1 : Γ t ∈ convexHull ℝ {Γ 0, Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ 0, Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))} := by
      apply Convex.combo_convex_hull
      <;> aesop
    exact h1
  · -- Show that the rectangle has area 1/4 and is a rectangle
    simp [dist_eq_norm, Real.angle_eq_pi_div_two]
    <;> norm_num
    <;> aesop
```

```lean4
theorem putnam_1969_b4
    (Γ : ℝ → EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
    --Note: the problem doesn't say what regularity conditions we should impose on `Γ` - hopefully continuity is enough.
    (Γ_cts : ContinuousOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1))
    (hΓ : eVariationOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1) = 1) :
    letI : Module.Oriented ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) (Fin 2) := ⟨Module.Basis.orientation <| Pi.basisFun _ _⟩
    letI : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) = 2) := ⟨finrank_euclideanSpace_fin⟩
    ∃ (a b c d : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ '' (Set.Icc 0 1) ⊆
      convexHull ℝ {a, b, c, d} ∧ dist a b * dist b c = 1/4 ∧
      --`abcd` is a rectangle
      letI π_div_2 := Real.Angle.coe <| π / 2
      (∡ a b c = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ b c d = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ c d a = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ d a b = π_div_2) := by
  classical
  use Γ 0, Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ 0 + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) + (1 / 2 : ℝ) • (1 : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
  constructor
  · -- Show that the image of Γ is contained in the convex hull of the four points
    intro x hx
    have h1 : x ∈ Γ '' Set.Icc 0 1 := hx
    rcases h1 with ⟨t, ⟨ht1, ht2⟩, rfl⟩
    simp_all [convexHull_singleton]
    <;>
    (try
      norm_num) <;>
    (try
      aesop) <;>
    (try
      exact
        Set.mem_of_mem_of_subset
          (Set.mem_convexHull.mpr
            ⟨1 / 2, 1 / 2, by norm_num, by norm_num, by simp_all [Fin.sum_univ_succ] <;> aesop⟩)
          (convexHull_mono <| by aesop)) <;>
    (try
      aesop)
  · -- Show that the product of the distances is 1/4 and the angles are π/2
    constructor
    · -- Show that the product of the distances is 1/4
      simp [dist_eq_norm, norm_eq_abs, abs_of_nonneg, add_nonneg, mul_comm]
      <;>
      ring_nf <;>
      norm_num <;>
      aesop
    · -- Show that the angles are π/2
      constructor
      · -- ∡ a b c = π_div_2
        simp [Real.Angle.coe, Real.Angle.pi_div_two]
        <;> aesop
      · constructor
        · -- ∡ b c d = π_div_2
          simp [Real.Angle.coe, Real.Angle.pi_div_two]
          <;> aesop
        · constructor
          · -- ∡ c d a = π_div_2
            simp [Real.Angle.coe, Real.Angle.pi_div_two]
            <;> aesop
          · -- ∡ d a b = π_div_2
            simp [Real.Angle.coe, Real.Angle.pi_div_two]
            <;> aesop
```

theorem putnam_1969_b4
    (Γ : ℝ → EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
    --Note: the problem doesn't say what regularity conditions we should impose on `Γ` - hopefully continuity is enough.
    (Γ_cts : ContinuousOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1))
    (hΓ : eVariationOn Γ (Set.Icc 0 1) = 1) :
    letI : Module.Oriented ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) (Fin 2) := ⟨Module.Basis.orientation <| Pi.basisFun _ _⟩
    letI : Fact (Module.finrank ℝ (EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)) = 2) := ⟨finrank_euclideanSpace_fin⟩
    ∃ (a b c d : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2)), Γ '' (Set.Icc 0 1) ⊆
      convexHull ℝ {a, b, c, d} ∧ dist a b * dist b c = 1/4 ∧
      --`abcd` is a rectangle
      letI π_div_2 := Real.Angle.coe <| π / 2
      (∡ a b c = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ b c d = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ c d a = π_div_2 ∧ ∡ d a b = π_div_2) := by

  constructor
  · -- Show that the image of Γ is contained in the convex hull of the points {a, b, c, d}

      intro x hx
      rw [Set.mem_image] at hx
      rcases hx with ⟨t, ht, rfl⟩
      exact convexHull_singleton_subset_convexHull (Set.mem_insert_iff.mpr (Or.inl rfl))

  · -- Show that the product of the distances is 1/4 and the angles are π/2

    · -- Show that the product of the distances is 1/4
      simp [dist_eq_norm]
    · -- Show that the angles are π/2
      constructor
      · -- Angle a b c is π/2
        simp [angle_eq_pi_div_two]
      · constructor
        · -- Angle b c d is π/2
          simp [angle_eq_pi_div_two]
        · constructor
          · -- Angle c d a is π/2
            simp [angle_eq_pi_div_two]
          · -- Angle d a b is π/2
            simp [angle_eq_pi_div_two]
